text: To work in the UK as a seasonal worker, you needs to apply through the Seasonal Workers’ Scheme if you don’t already have the right to work in the UK.
The Seasonal Workers’ Scheme has five approved operators who recruit workers and sponsor visas for seasonal horticultural work like picking fruit or vegetables.

The five Scheme Operators are AGRI-hr (https://www.agri-hr.com), Concordia (UK) Ltd (https://www.concordia.org.uk/seasonal-work), Fruitful Jobs (https://www.fruitfuljobs.com/seasonal-worker-scheme), HOPS Labour Solutions Ltd (https://www.hopslaboursolutions.com/sws), and Pro-Force Limited (https://www.pro-force.co.uk/support/visa-information). No other employer can legally provide a seasonal worker visa or work.
Some Scheme Operators may use recruitment agents in worker’s country, which can be government or private agencies. Only use agents listed on the operator’s website.
Some operators only recruit from certain countries, so worker should check the link to see if worker’s country is accepted.

Worker should not pay any agent or business to get a job. Worker should only pay for the visa application fee and appointment (via https://www.gov.uk/find-a-visa-application-centre), travel costs to and from the UK, and any required fees to worker’s home country government.
If asked to pay other fees, worker should contact their operator.

To avoid scams online, worker should ensure communications are from a genuine Scheme Operator, not via WhatsApp or Telegram, and check contact details on the operator’s website. Worker should not give personal details unless it’s a verified operator and should not post them publicly.
Scheme operators will never ask worker for payment during recruitment. If worker has concerns, contact the Scheme Operator or an approved agent.
Horticultural Seasonal Workers can work in the UK for up to 6 months in any 12-month period and must wait 6 months before returning on a new visa. Worker cannot apply for an extension to stay.

Farms may ask good workers to return, but worker must go through a Scheme Operator for a certificate of sponsorship. Employers notify operators, and the operator will contact worker about returning, but worker cannot apply for a visa more than 12 weeks before returning.

Q: Should I pay an agent to find me a job?
A: No. It is illegal for an agent to charge you a fee to find you work in the UK. 

Some dishonest recruitment agents will ask for money to provide work in the UK. Charging a fee for work-finding services is illegal in the UK so if any agent asks you for money, do not use that agent. You should not be charged any fees for your application, interview, documents or contract. If you are asked to pay these, or other fees, report it to your Scheme Operator.
Agents should never ask you for money as part of the recruitment process. Charging fees for work-finding services is illegal in the UK.

The United Kingdom is made up of four countries: England, Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland. Cities are diverse with many options for entertainment, while rural areas are quieter. British people are friendly but also respectful of personal space and privacy. It is considered rude to push in front of a queue; you must wait your turn. At work, a handshake is a correct greeting. You are expected to be on time for work and social events. UK culture values equality and respect for all people.
English is the main language used in all parts of the UK, but there are other official languages such as Welsh in Wales, and Irish and Gaelic in other regions.

In the UK, it is common to meet friends in a pub for drinks. You must be 18 years of age or older to legally purchase alcohol and may have to show proof of your age. It is illegal to buy alcohol for someone who is under 18. It is never acceptable to drink alcohol or be drunk when you are driving or working.

The weather in the UK is very unpredictable; it can be cold and wet at any time of year. Rain is frequent, but snow is rare in most areas. Summer temperatures rarely get higher than 30 degrees Celsius. It is generally colder in the northern parts of the country. It is highly recommended to bring a warm, waterproof coat.
Smaller towns and rural areas are usually less diverse, quieter, and more traditionally British.
British people value personal space and it is considered rude to stand too close to someone unless necessary (e.g., on a crowded train).
British people often apologize even if they're not at fault — for example, if someone bumps into them, they might say 'Sorry!'
British people respect privacy and do not typically discuss personal relationships or business with strangers or casual acquaintances.
It is considered rude to push ahead in a queue in the UK. Always wait your turn politely.
In the workplace, a handshake is the standard greeting. In other situations, a smile and nod are acceptable ways to greet others.
Punctuality is important in the UK. You are expected to be on time for both work and social engagements.
UK culture values equality and respect. Everyone should be treated respectfully regardless of position, age, gender, religion, ethnicity, sexuality, or disability.
English is spoken throughout the UK. Other official languages include Welsh (spoken in Wales), Irish, and Scottish Gaelic.
Drinking alcohol is common in social settings like pubs. You must be 18+ to buy alcohol and may need to show ID. It is illegal to buy alcohol for someone underage.
Drinking alcohol is common in social settings like pubs. You must be 18+ to buy alcohol and may need to show ID. It is illegal to buy alcohol for someone underage.
It is never acceptable to drink alcohol while working or driving. Doing so can result in legal consequences.
Summer temperatures rarely rise above 30°C in most parts of the UK.
Winters in northern parts of the UK and in Scotland can be very cold, with temperatures below freezing. Prepare with warm clothing and waterproof gear.
Due to frequent rain and cold weather, bring a warm, waterproof coat and appropriate clothing. Many older buildings are not well-heated.

The Seasonal Workers’ Visa allows you to work in the UK for up to 6 months in horticulture, for example harvesting fruit, vegetables or flowers. This kind of work involves physical labour and you need to be fit and strong.
Work placements on the Seasonal Workers Visa Scheme are an average of 20 weeks long, out of a maximum of 6 months.

When on the Seasonal Worker Scheme, you may not bring partners or children with you to the UK. You will also not receive any state benefits. The program is not a route to permanent settlement in the UK.

You may be refused entry to the UK if you have been convicted of a serious crime or have entered the UK illegally at any time. You may only work in the job you are sponsored for. You must leave the UK by the end of your visa and be able to provide evidence you have returned home.
To be accepted by a scheme operator as a seasonal worker, you must be at least 18 years old and have a clean criminal record.

As a qualification for the scheme, you must have no allergies that will affect you working at a farm and pass a health check to make sure you are fit for work. You also need to be fit and strong enough to lift and carry heavy loads and work quickly and carefully.
To qualify for the Seasonal Worker Scheme, you must have a biometric passport and have no previous visa violations.
The Seasonal Worker Scheme operators are the only agents who can sponsor a visa for the UK Seasonal Worker Scheme. You must be accepted for a job by an operator before you can apply for a visa.

If your job application is successful, you will receive a Certificate of Sponsorship from your scheme operator. This is a digital document with a reference number that contains job and personal details — it is not a physical certificate.
You will also receive a job offer that includes where you’ll work, what you’ll do, how much you’ll earn, and what you need to bring. Read this carefully and make sure you understand it.
You will also receive a job offer that includes where you’ll work, what you’ll do, how much you’ll earn, and what you need to bring. Read this carefully and make sure you understand it.
Your Scheme Operator may help you apply for your visa. However, there may be a fee for this assistance.
You can apply for your visa online at: https://apply-to-visit-or-stay-in-the-uk.homeoffice.gov.uk/sort/live-in-crown-dependency/temporary_work_out_uk?uid=06202755-95ce-4432-a3d7-aca5c262490c
You cannot apply for your visa until you have received a Certificate of Sponsorship from a Scheme Operator. Your operator may also assist with the visa application process.
Horticultural seasonal workers can work in the UK for a maximum of 6 months in any 12-month period. After leaving, you must wait 6 months before applying again.
Employers benefit from hiring returning workers. If your employer wants you back, they will notify the Scheme Operator. You must reapply through the operator — farms cannot hire you directly.

To apply for your visa, you will need:
1. An application fee of £298.00 paid online.
2. The sponsorship certificate reference number.
3. Proof of identity (biometric data or passport scan).
Although your Scheme Operator may support you during your first month in the UK, you should still arrive with £100–£200 to cover initial personal expenses.

You can prove your identity in two ways:
a) Visit a Visa Application Centre (VAC) for fingerprints and photo.
b) Use the 'UKVI ID Check' app if you're an EU national with a biometric passport.
After applying online and submitting documents, you'll usually get a decision within 3 weeks. During busy periods, it may take up to 6 weeks. Do not book travel until you have your visa.
Once your visa is approved, you can enter the UK as soon as your visa becomes valid.

To apply for a visa under the UK Seasonal Worker Scheme, you must first receive a job offer from one of the five approved Scheme Operators.
You must apply to the Seasonal Workers Scheme through one of the approved Scheme Operators.

After applying, the Scheme Operator will arrange an interview and provide information about available jobs in the UK. This is a good time to ask questions about the job, accommodation, and what you need to bring.

During the application process, you may be asked to provide:
- Contact information
- A medical check
- A clean criminal record check
- A valid passport
If your application is successful, you’ll receive a job offer and a certificate of sponsorship from your Scheme Operator. The offer should be in a language you understand.

It’s important to read your job offer carefully. It should explain:
- Where you’ll work
- What your wages will be
- How much you'll pay for accommodation
- Health and other insurance
- Other key details about your role
Your Scheme Operator can help with your visa application and answer any questions you have. Most operators provide this support, although some may charge a fee.
It is important to understand the costs involved in working as a seasonal worker in the UK to ensure it is financially worthwhile.

Under UK law, you should never be charged fees for:
- Being provided with work
- Training required for your job
- Necessary equipment or personal protective gear (PPE)
- Being assigned a specific job or shift pattern

You are responsible for paying for:
- Your travel to and from the UK
- Your visa application fee
- Food and accommodation while in the UK
If you're paid at the National Minimum Wage in England, your accommodation may cost up to £74.62 per week.

In Scotland, if you're earning the National Minimum Wage, you may be charged up to £10.66 per day for accommodation.

[More details on Scottish accommodation fees](https://www.sasa.gov.uk/covid-19-guidance/seasonal-agricultural-workers )
If you earn more than the National Minimum Wage, you may be charged more for accommodation than the standard rates.
Make sure to read your job offer and contract carefully to understand all costs, especially related to accommodation and other deductions.

source: 2.4 Your Contract and Rights - Language Requirement
text: You must be given an employment contract in a language you understand and in English.

source: 2.4 Your Contract and Rights - Minimum Hours
text: You have the right to be paid at least 32 hours per week averaged over your pay period. This is dependent on your working hours offered. If you are offered work and you do not attend, you will not be paid for the hours you miss. "Zero-hours" contracts which do not give you minimum hours are not allowed.

source: 2.4 Your Contract and Rights - Time Off and Breaks
text: You must be allowed time off and breaks.

source: 2.4 Your Contract and Rights - Sick or Injured
text: You must be clearly told what to do if you are sick or injured at work and how to make a claim on any insurance you may have.
Your accommodation should be clean and safe and in good condition.
You must be transported in safe vehicles.

source: 2.4 Your Contract and Rights - Threats and Violence
text: You should not be threatened or treated with violence.

source: 2.4 Your Contract and Rights - Passport and Documents
text: Your passports, identity documents and travel papers should never be kept from you. Copies of these documents may be taken but you should have access to all of your original documents at all times.

source: 2.4 Your Contract and Rights - Scotland-Specific Rules
text: If you are working in Scotland, there are different laws that apply in regard to your rights and contract. You can find out more about your rights and contract in Scotland in this factsheet (available in several languages). (https://www.sasa.gov.uk/covid-19-guidance/seasonal-agricultural-workers )

Your scheme operator will advise you on how to travel to the UK. You can arrange your own transport, or they may offer some options. The UK has 29 international airports, so be sure to find out which airport is the best one to fly to for your specific farm.

source: 2.8 Getting from the Airport to the Farm
text: You must plan and arrange your journey to the farm before you travel. You may be able to get a train or coach to a town near the farm and then get picked up. Do not get into a taxi at an airport to take you to a farm, as this will be very expensive. If you arrive with a group, most farms will arrange for your travel from the airport, but you may have to pay for it.

If you are traveling from Europe with a car, you can book a ferry to travel across the English Channel or use the Euro Tunnel from France. If you don’t have a car, you can still travel on ferries as a foot passenger, or get a train or coach from several European cities.
Please be aware that most growers will not allow cars onsite. You must check with your operator before you leave if you wish to bring a car, as it is not always possible.
Warning: You must refuse to carry any packages for someone else to the UK. You are legally responsible for everything you bring into the country, even if it is not yours.
You may have problems or concerns about your work, pay, working conditions, or relationships with other workers that you need help to resolve.
You may just need to talk with your manager to get a complaint resolved. Your contract should explain the process for making a complaint.
You can also contact your Scheme Operator if the farm is not resolving your problem.
If you are not able to resolve your complaint informally, or if your issue is very serious and you need to take it further, you can begin the process of raising a grievance.
A grievance is a formal procedure which your employer is legally required to follow.
The process for raising a grievance should also be outlined in your contract. If not, you can contact ACAS for advice.
You can also see the Get Help section for more organisations that can help you if you have a problem at work that is not solved by your employer.
When you apply for a job, they’ll ask about your health to check if you’re fit for the work.
Employers want to make sure you don’t have allergies or health issues that stop you from working on a farm.
You need to be fit, flexible, and strong to do the job.
If you don’t tell them about any health problems, it might mess up or invalidate your health insurance.
You’ll get training to understand the risks of your job and how to work safely.
The training will show you how to use equipment safely and avoid getting hurt.
You’ll learn what to do in an emergency, like a fire.
You must be paid for any safety training, even before you start the job.
All new workers get basic training on safe practices, including first aid.
